journal-meta.journal-title: The American Journal of Sports Medicine

title-group.article-title: The Effects of Chlorhexidine Graft Decontamination on Tendon Graft Collagen and Cell Viability

article-meta.aff: †Orthopaedic Department, College of Medicine, King Saud University, Riyadh, Saudi Arabia
‡Orthopaedic Research Laboratory, Division of Orthopaedic Surgery, McGill University, Montreal, Quebec, Canada
§Shriners Hospital for Children, McGill University, Montreal, Quebec, Canada

Investigation performed at the Orthopaedic Research Laboratory, Royal Victoria Hospital; and the Shriners Hospital for Children, Montreal, Quebec, Canada

author-notes.corresp: *Abdulaziz Z. Alomar, MD, MSc, FRCSC, Orthopaedic Department, College of Medicine, King Saud University, Building No. 34, Office No. 49, PO Box 7805, Riyadh, Saudi Arabia 11472 (e-mail: dr_abdulaziz@yahoo.com).

permissions.copyright-holder: American Orthopaedic Society for Sports Medicine

sec.title: Background:
sec.p: Chlorhexidine (CLX) has been reported as a popular and effective disinfectant of contaminated tendon grafts with no biomechanical sequelae; however, its biochemical effects on tendon collagen and fibroblasts remain unknown.

sec.title: Purpose:
sec.p: To determine whether CLX disinfection of contaminated tendon grafts has deleterious effects on tendon collagen or a toxic effect on fibroblast function.

sec.title: Study Design:
sec.p: Controlled laboratory study.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: Collagen fibrils prepared from purified bovine collagen type I were treated with various CLX concentrations (0.5%-4%) and incubation times (10-40 minutes), and the effects on fibril degradation and solubility were then examined using gel electrophoresis. Fresh bovine tendons were treated with sterile water or 2% CLX; then, fibroblast mobility and metabolic activity were evaluated using light microscopy and Alamar Blue assay, respectively.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: No effect on collagen fibrils was observed when they were exposed to 0%, 0.5%, or 2% CLX at any exposure time. However, 4% CLX dissolved the fibrils even after short incubation times. Fibroblasts migrated out from the control tendon explants but not from explants treated with 2% CLX, and a 5-fold reduction in metabolic activity was observed throughout the tendon in explants exposed to 2% CLX, suggesting that CLX penetrated and killed cells throughout the tissue.

sec.title: Conclusion:
sec.p: Four-percent CLX caused collagen fibrils to dissolve in vitro, and tendon graft disinfection with 2% CLX was cytotoxic to the cells.

sec.title: Clinical Relevance:
sec.p: Because of its chemical effect on tendon collagen and cytotoxic effect on tendon fibroblasts, 4% CLX should not be used as a disinfectant. Two-percent CLX can be used to disinfect contaminated ACL grafts, but such treatment will drastically reduce the metabolic activity of the cells within the graft, making it similar to an acellular allograft tendon.

body.p: Anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) reconstruction is a commonly performed procedure in orthopaedic surgery today, with more than 100,000 ACL reconstructions performed annually in the United States.16,19 Both tendon autografts and allografts have been used successfully in ACL reconstruction.6,30,32 Great care must be taken to avoid contamination during harvest and/or preparation of the graft for ACL reconstruction or any other surgical procedure. Handling and carrying the grafts between the operative table and side table raise the possibility of accidental graft contamination. As orthopaedic surgeons continue to increase the use of both autografts and allografts for reconstruction of soft tissues, demand for a safe, effective, and expeditious means to disinfect any accidentally contaminated tissue will increase.

If the graft is contaminated because of accidental dropping on the floor, graft disinfection is a viable option.4,16,19 Different studies on disinfecting contaminated grafts have demonstrated that chlorhexidine (CLX) is the most efficient and effective protocol.4,13,26 Both 2% and 4% CLX concentration have been used effectively.4,13 Although data on the clinical outcomes of using CLX are still lacking, no reported cases in the literature in which CLX was used to disinfect the ACL graft developed infection.19,29 Three liters of 2% CLX power irrigation can be effectively used to disinfect a contaminated ACL graft without weakening the graft.16 However, the biochemical effects of CLX on the tendon are still unknown.

The main purpose of our biochemical study was to determine if there would be any adverse biochemical effect of the ACL decontamination solution on treated ACL grafts. Because the major constituent of tendon is type I collagen (86% fat-free dry weight) and the primary cell type in tendon is the fibroblast, the focus of this study was to investigate the biochemical effects of CLX on both collagen (type I) and fibroblasts. Our hypothesis was that CLX is cytotoxic to fibroblasts and adversely affects the biochemical properties of collagen. To the best of our knowledge, this study is the first to test the biochemical effect of CLX on collagen and tendon fibroblasts.

sec.title: Collagen Fibril Formation
sec.p: Commercially available purified collagen dissolved in 0.012 N HCl (Vitrogen 100, Advanced BioMatrix, San Diego, California) composed of 97% collagen type I and 3% collagen type III was used to prepare collagen fibrils to study the effect of CLX on collagen degradation and dissolution. Collagen fibrils were prepared as described by Geng et al.10 Soluble collagen (5 µg in 3.5 µL) was mixed with 21.5 µL of 10 mM HCl and 25 µL of 2× TES buffer (60 mM TES, 20 mM Na2HPO4, 0.56 M NaCl, pH 7.6), incubated at 37°C for 1 hour, and then centrifuged for 5 minutes at 13,000 rpm. The supernatant was removed, and the pellets containing self-assembled collagen fibrils were saved (Figure 1).

caption.p: A flowchart of the collagen experimental design.

sec.title: Collagen Fibril Exposure to CLX
sec.p: Chlorhexidine was diluted in sterile reverse osmosis water (18.2 mΩ) from a 20% commercially available CLX solution (Dexidin 20, Laboratoire Atlas, Montreal, Canada). Reverse osmosis water without CLX was used as a control. The newly formed collagen fibrils prepared as described above were incubated with 50 µL of CLX at various concentrations (0%, 0.5%, 2%, and 4%) and for different incubation times (10, 20, and 40 minutes). After the incubation period, CLX was removed, and the fibrils were collected by centrifugation. A second set of collagen fibrils was prepared as described above and exposed to 50 µL of 0%, 2%, or 4% CLX for 20 minutes. After exposure, both pellets and supernatants were analyzed by gel electrophoresis as described below.

sec.title: Gel Electrophoresis
sec.p: Dissolved collagen present in the supernatants was precipitated by the addition of 95% ethanol (1:9 vol:vol) at 4°C overnight and recovered by centrifugation. Protein pellets were washed twice in 75% ethanol, lyophilized, mixed with SDS/polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (PAGE) sample buffer, and boiled for 5 minutes. Collagen fibril pellets were directly resuspended in SDS/PAGE sample buffer and boiled for 5 minutes. The samples were separated by SDS/PAGE (8% NOVEX gels, Invitrogen, Carlsbad, California) under reducing conditions, and the gels were stained with Coomassie Blue (Bio-Rad Laboratories Inc, Hercules, California). The amount of collagen in both supernatants and pellets was measured by assessing the number of pixels in bands visualized using a Syngene gel imaging system (Cambridge, United Kingdom).

sec.title: Tendon Explant Preparation
sec.p: Bovine hoofs from skeletally mature animals, aged 2 years, were obtained from a local abattoir within 6 hours of death. The hoofs were washed once with 70% ethanol followed by sterile distilled water. The skin and deep fascia were cut open to expose the muscles and tendons. The deep digital flexor tendon was dissected by cutting and separating the tendon from the third phalanx. The upper part of the tendon was already freed during dismembering of the knee joint. The thin tendon sheath was dissected and removed. The tendon was cut at its junction and divided into 2 segments. One of the segments from each hoof was taken as a control and the other for experimentation (2% CLX exposure) (Figure 2).

caption.p: A flowchart of the fibroblast experimental design.

sec.title: Disinfection With CLX and Subsequent Explant Culture
sec.p: The tendons were soaked in 200 mL of 2% CLX or reverse osmosis water, prepared as described above, for 10 minutes. They were then washed separately 3 times for 5 minutes each in 200 mL Dulbecco’s phosphate buffered saline (PBS) (free from Ca2+ and Mg2+). One-centimeter-wide explants were cut at a distance of 1, 2, and 3 cm from the ankle joint end of the tendon (Figure 3). The method of isolation and culturing the fibroblasts has been described before.37 The explants were placed in 6-well culture plates (Corning, Corning, New York) and cultured in 5 mL/well of Dulbecco’s modified Eagle’s medium (Sigma, St Louis, Missouri) supplemented with 4.5 g/L glucose, 25 mM HEPES (Sigma), 100 U/mL penicillin, 100 µg/mL streptomycin (Gibco, Carlsbad, California), 0.25 µg/mL fungizone (Gibco), 50 µg/mL l-ascorbate, 5% fetal bovine serum (Invitrogen), and 2 mM GlutaMAX (Sigma) in a standard incubator at 37°C and 5% CO2.

caption.p: Point of division of deep digital flexor tendon and designation of tendon limbs as control (C) and experimental (E). Boxes indicate sites at which tendon explants were collected, each piece measuring 1 cm and taken at a distance of 1, 2, or 3 cm from the ankle joint end of the tendon segment. Tendon slices were collected from the middle of each tendon piece (parallel lines, inset) and incubated with 10% Alamar Blue dye for 6 hours.

sec.title: Metabolic Activity of Tendon Fibroblasts
sec.p: After 48 hours in culture, a full-thickness, 1-mm-wide slice was excised from the middle of each 1-cm tendon piece and weighed (Figure 3). These slices were then placed in a 48-well culture plate (NUNC, Roskilde, Denmark) and incubated in a standard incubator at 37°C and 5% CO2 for 6 hours in 1 mL of 10% Alamar Blue (Invitrogen) diluted in the medium described above. After incubation, 100 µL of the solution was transferred to a 96-well, clear-bottom black plate (Corning), and relative fluorescence was measured (excitation, 540 nm; emission, 585 nm) using an Infinite M200 Pro plate reader (Tecan GmbH, Grödig, Austria). Each tissue slice was analyzed in triplicate. Relative fluorescence was normalized to tissue weight, and results were plotted as relative fluorescence units (RFU)/100-mg tissue weight.1,27 Data from 2 replicates were combined, and means and standard deviations (SDs) were calculated.

sec.title: Mobility of CLX-Treated Tendon Fibroblasts
sec.p: Tendon segments taken at 1 cm from the cut surface (Figure 3) were placed at the bottom of a 6-well culture plate (Corning) and cultured as described above for 5 days. Fibroblast viability was assessed in control and 2% CLX–exposed pieces by evaluating the ability of cells to migrate out of the tendon piece and spread at the bottom of the well. At the end of the culture period, the control and 2% CLX–exposed tendon-containing wells were visualized under an inverted light microscope (Axiovert 135, Zeiss, Jena, Germany) at 10× magnification.

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: Statistical analysis was performed using NCSS statistical software (version 2004, Kaysville, Utah). Continuous data were expressed as mean ± SD. Differences were studied using 2-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) with post hoc analysis using the Newman-Keuls test for multiple comparisons. The threshold for statistical significance was set at P < .05.

sec.title: CLX Effect on Collagen Fibrils
sec.p: SDS/PAGE showed no effect on collagen fibrils treated with 0.5% or 2% CLX concentrations at all exposure times as compared with the 0% control group. However, significantly fewer collagen fibrils were detected after treatment with 4% CLX at all exposure times (Figure 4).

caption.p: Gel electrophoresis of collagen fibrils after chlorhexidine (CLX) treatment. The gel shows loss of collagen fibrils with 4% CLX, whereas no collagen loss or degradation was seen at 0.5% and 2% CLX at various exposure durations. The migration position of intact collagen polypeptide chains (α1(I) and α2(I)) is indicated.

sec.p: To determine if CLX degrades or dissolves collagen fibrils, the experiment was repeated using 2% or 4% CLX for 20 minutes, and both supernatants and fibril pellets were analyzed by electrophoresis. The concentration of 0.5% was not repeated in this section because, like 2%, it has no effect on the collagen fibrils. Upon exposure to 4% CLX, the fibrils were dissolved, and the majority of the collagen was found as intact polypeptide chains in the supernatant (Figure 5), indicating that exposure to 4% CLX dissociated the fibrils but did not result in their degradation. In the fibrils treated with 2% CLX, no free chains were detected in the supernatant, indicating that this concentration does not dissociate the fibrils.

caption.p: Gel electrophoresis of fibrillar (pellet) and solubilized (supernatant) collagen after chlorhexidine (CLX) treatment. The gel shows the presence of only solubilized intact collagen molecules when fibrils were exposed to 4% CLX but of only fibrillar collagen when the fibrils were exposed to water (control). P, pellet; S, supernatant.

sec.p: The intensity of the Coomassie-stained collagen bands was assessed by Image J (http://rsb.info.nih.gov/ij/) analysis of scanned gels for both pellets and supernatants. There was significantly more dissolved collagen in the supernatant of 4% CLX–treated fibrils compared with untreated fibrils or those treated with 2% CLX (P = .000001). No significant difference in the amount of fibrils was observed between the 2% CLX and control group in either the pellet (P = .4) or supernatant (P = .16) (Figure 6).

caption.p: Proportion of fibrillar and soluble collagen after the fibrils have been exposed to reverse osmosis water or 2% or 4% chlorhexidine for 20 minutes. The relative abundance of fibrillar (pellet) and soluble (supernatant) collagen was assessed using ImageJ analysis of scanned gels.

sec.title: Cytotoxic Effect of CLX Disinfection
sec.p: Chlorhexidine is known to be cytotoxic to cultured monolayer cells, but it is not known if it can penetrate an intact tendon graft and affect cells inside the tissue after CLX decontamination. To determine the effect of CLX on cell viability, tendon grafts were treated with 2% CLX for 10 minutes, washed in PBS, and then maintained in explant culture for 48 hours. The medium in control wells changed color with time, indicating the presence of viable metabolizing cells. In contrast, tendon pieces exposed to 2% CLX showed reduced medium color change, suggesting compromised cell viability. Analysis of the tendon sections using the Alamar Blue assay (Invitrogen) showed that the metabolic activity of the cells in the control samples was 5 times higher than that of cells in the treated group (Figure 7), suggesting loss of viable cells in the tendon pieces disinfected with 2% CLX. The reduction in metabolic activity was consistent throughout the tendon, indicating that CLX penetrates and kills the cells throughout the entire tissue.

caption.p: Metabolic activity of control and 2% chlorhexidine–treated tendon slices. The relative fluorescence was normalized to tissue weight and is presented as relative fluorescence units (RFU)/100-mg tissue weight.

sec.title: Effect of CLX Disinfection on Fibroblast Mobility
sec.p: Tendon pieces harvested and treated as described above were cultured for 5 days to allow fibroblasts to migrate out of the tissue. At the end of the culture period, the bottom of the wells was visualized under a light microscope. At the bottom of the control wells were colonies of healthy viable cells that had migrated out of the explants. In contrast, 2% CLX–exposed tendon cultures contained no cell colonies at the bottoms of wells, indicating the failure of fibroblast migration and supporting the loss of viable cells within the explant (Figure 8).

caption.p: Microscopic image of fibroblasts that have migrated from a bovine tendon explant. Viable cells were observed from explants irrigated with reverse osmosis water (A), whereas no viable cells were observed from explants irrigated with 2% chlorhexidine (B).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: It is known that 2% and 4% CLX are efficacious in sterilizing contaminated tissues.4,13 However, it is not known what is the biological and biochemical effect of CLX on tendons. This study shows that CLX is cytotoxic to fibroblasts at a lower concentration (2%) and dissolves collagen fibrils at a higher concentration (4%).

The management of inadvertent intraoperative contamination of an ACL graft during ACL reconstruction poses a challenging dilemma to the orthopaedic surgeon, and insufficient data are available in the literature to support the most appropriate cleansing methods. The most commonly reported mechanism of contamination is accidentally dropping the tendon graft onto the floor.5,19,29 Studies have reported positive culture rates of 58% to 60% when the graft was dropped in the operating room.7,29 If the graft is dropped, several possible options are available for salvage: disinfecting the graft, using an alternative graft (autograft or allograft), or stopping the procedure and completing the surgery at another time with a different graft. Cleansing the graft avoids further morbidity to the patient or the cost of an allograft but has the potential risk of joint sepsis. A previously reported survey of sports medicine specialists (196 surgeons) revealed that 25% of surgeons have had at least one such incident of graft dropping.19 Furthermore, most of those surgeons (75%) chose cleansing the graft to manage the problem of a dropped graft, and chlorhexidine gluconate (CLX) was the antiseptic agent most commonly used. However, no consensus on the CLX concentration or the method and time of decontamination protocols has been achieved.19

If the graft cleansing option is chosen, the operative team must weigh the risk of an infectious complication after reimplantation against that of discarding a potentially contaminated tendon graft. A contaminated graft implanted in the knee could be a risk factor for septic arthritis, which is a rare but devastating complication after ACL reconstruction.25 Such concerns necessitate further investigation into the optimal cleansing protocol to avoid infection and disinfect the graft without affecting its biochemical or biomechanical properties.

Chlorhexidine is a cationic bisbiguanide with excellent antimicrobial action that is widely used for topical preoperative skin disinfection, general skin cleansing, and as a surgical hand scrub.18 It is active against a wide range of microorganisms, being bacteriostatic at low concentrations and bactericidal at higher concentrations.28 Chlorhexidine is also fungicidal but does not destroy bacterial spores or mycobacterial species,35 and it shows activity against enveloped viruses.22 Its mechanism of action involves membrane disruption and not ATPase inactivation as previously thought.22

Because the reported literature about the disinfectant ability of CLX has variability in the time and concentration when used for tendon graft decontamination,4,13 varying concentrations and incubation times were used in this study. Our results showed that CLX at concentrations of 0.5% and 2% did not adversely affect the integrity of self-assembled collagen fibrils regardless of incubation time. No free chains were found in the supernatant as 2% CLX at this concentration does not solubilize the newly formed fibrils. This indicates that the collagen molecules remain intact as insoluble fibers in the pellet.

Therefore, irrigating the tendon with 0.5% or 2% CLX is unlikely to adversely affect its biomechanical properties. This finding is consistent with the results of the study by Han et al,16 which reported that disinfecting tendons with 2% CLX power irrigation did not adversely weaken the tensile mechanical properties of the tendon. Our experiments showed that 4% CLX has the ability to dissociate newly formed collagen that is not yet cross-linked. It might thereby impair deposition of newly synthesized collagen essential for graft integration. Although the biomechanical and the in vivo biochemical effects of 4% CLX on mature cross-linked collagen that is already deposited in the tendons are still unknown, we think that the ability of 4% CLX to dissociate collagen fibrils might adversely affect the biomechanical graft tendon properties. Therefore, 4% CLX should not be used for graft cleansing.

Regardless of what type of tendon autograft is used (bone-tendon-bone [BTB] or bone free), viable tendon fibroblasts play an important role in early graft incorporation. Histological analysis of fibroblasts after ACL reconstruction with a BTB autograft in a human model34 and with a soft tissue (bone-free) autograft in a dog model33 showed that the fibroblasts play an important role in autograft incorporation (ligamentization) after reconstruction.

The abundance of viable fibroblasts may explain why graft incorporation is faster with autografts as compared with allografts.20 Recently, Scheffler et al36 demonstrated significantly lower overall cellularity in ovine allograft recipients versus autograft recipients at 6 weeks. The present work demonstrates that 2% CLX can have a detrimental effect on cell viability. Thus, for tendon autografts, using CLX for disinfection may have adverse affects on graft incorporation into the bone after surgery because of the loss of viable fibroblasts, which would make the tendon autograft behave biologically like an allograft in which fibroblasts are killed during the sterilization process. Despite the lack of scientific evidence, some orthopaedic surgeons prefer to go slowly and with longer rehabilitation and more delay to return to sport with allografts compared with autografts. We think any autograft treated with CLX may considered as an allograft as regards biological incorporation to the bone; therefore, postoperative rehabilitation may need to have a longer duration and be less intense with possibly more delay to return to sport.

The important question of whether CLX has the ability to penetrate deep into the tendon or whether its cytotoxic effects are limited to the exposed surface of the tendon has also been addressed in this study. Despite washing the tendon after being treated with CLX, 2% CLX was not only cytotoxic to tendon fibroblasts close to cut surfaces but also was able to penetrate and kill cells throughout the tissue. Furthermore, the cytotoxic effect of CLX was observed even with minimal contact time (10 minutes).

Both power irrigation4 and soaking of tendons in CLX13 have been described as effective methods of tendon decontamination. In this study, we used the soaking method because we think it has better control in the amount and time of CLX exposure; however, we believe the cytotoxic effect of CLX can be seen in both methods.

Several studies have shown that CLX has toxic effects on a variety of eukaryotic cells.2,9,14,17,21 Various reports have also indicated that CLX negatively affects cell proliferation. An in vitro study evaluating the mechanisms underlying CLX-induced toxicity on human dermal fibroblasts showed that CLX exerted an inhibitory concentration-dependent effect on DNA synthesis at concentrations as low as 0.0001% and that CLX concentrations of 0.005% or more were required for total cell death.18 Lucarotti et al23 observed 95% cytotoxicity when human fibroblasts were exposed to 0.0001% CLX for 24 hours. Cytotoxicity after 1, 24, and 72 hours in human gingival fibroblasts was also reported by Babich et al.2 Mariotti and Rumpf24 suggest that CLX exposure for short periods of time (1, 5, and 15 minutes) induces a dose-dependent reduction in cellular proliferation. Giannelli et al12 investigated the in vitro effect of CLX on osteoblast, endothelial, and fibroblast cells and found that CLX affected cell viability in a dose- and time-dependent manner, particularly in osteoblasts. A deleterious effect of CLX on articular cartilage has also been reported previously. Several case reports have shown that exposure of human articular cartilage to CLX for prolonged periods (such as during arthroscopic surgery), at low (0.02%) as well as high concentrations, results in severe chondrolysis and subsequent joint damage.5,8,38

In contrast, other studies have shown that CLX in the appropriate concentrations has no negative effects.3,8,11,15,28 At 0.05% concentration, CLX demonstrated no adverse effects on wound healing.31 The same concentration has also been used to treat a variety of bone and prosthetic infections11 and has been reported to give good results when used for treating septic arthritis in children.15

This study did not set out to test different concentrations of CLX for its disinfectant ability, that already has been previously published.4,13 Burd et al4 evaluated varying concentrations of CLX to determine the lowest effective concentration of solution that was able to completely decontaminate a tendon graft. They tested concentrations of 0.05%, 0.1%, 0.5%, 1%, 2%, and 4%. Only the 2% and 4% solutions demonstrated no bacterial growth. All the lower concentrations could not effectively decontaminate the grafts. The authors also showed that there was no difference in results in using either the 2% or 4% solutions. Given these findings, using a concentration lower than 2% CLX would not be clinically relevant in the setting of accidentally dropping an ACL graft and attempting to decontaminate it with a cleansing solution. With this knowledge, the next question that needed to be addressed was the one studied in our current study. Does the bacteriologically effective solution (2% and 4% CLX) adversely affect the grafts from a biochemical point of view?

Our study, therefore, only sought to determine the detrimental effects of exposure to 2% and 4% CLX, as the lower concentrations would be clinically irrelevant from a bacteriological point of view. We did, however, expose collagen in our study to 0.5% CLX and found no effect on the collagen. The 2% solution was found to be cytotoxic to the fibroblasts, but given the lack of clinical relevance to any concentration below 2%, we found it unnecessary to continue to test the lower concentration solutions. Therefore, our study did not attempt to define the lowest CLX concentration at which cell viability can be maintained.

While most previous reports of toxicity and complications involved direct lavage with CLX,5,8,38 implantation of a CLX-treated tendon graft during ACL reconstruction may potentially have a deleterious side effect when it comes in direct contact with bone cells on the ACL bony tunnels or chondrocytes of the intra-articular cartilage. Despite the lack of supporting evidence, we think that grafts that undergo CLX disinfection may be better if carefully rinsed with a copious amount of normal saline for a sufficient time before implantation into a joint. A continuous, arthroscopic, normal saline irrigation after graft implementation may be considered a good way to achieve this rinsing.

In conclusion, using 4% CLX can result in marked fibril dissolution and decreased cell viability and metabolic activity and, therefore, definitively should be avoided for use as a disinfectant. Two-percent CLX disinfection of tendon grafts, however, is an effective way to sterilize contaminated grafts while preserving collagen fibril integrity and biomechanical properties. It does, however, render the autograft to acellular tissue through its effect on fibroblast viability. Future studies will involve determining the effects of CLX on autograft incorporation and evaluating the toxicity effects of CLX on bone and cartilage.

ack.p: The authors thank Dr Margaret Durko for her assistance in organizing the collection of bovine hock specimens from Abattoir & Boucherie B. Poirier Inc.
